{{< var course.subtitle >}} author: '{{< var instructor.name >}}' subtitle: Policy · Themes date: December 02, 2024 date-format: long from: markdown+emoji bibliography: ../../data/lit/wipol_advanced.bib csl: ../../data/lit/wipol.csl execute: freeze: auto echo: true fig-width: 6 fig-height: 5 format: revealjs: theme: ../econpol_slides.scss footer: '{{< var course.number >}} {{< var course.title >}} | {{< var course.semester >}}' logo: ../../data/img/wu-logo-simple.png header-includes: | slide-number: true show-slide-number: all transition: fade progress: true multiplex: false scrollable: false preview-links: false hide-inactive-cursor: true highlight-style: printing pause: true --- # Fiscal policy
![](../../data/img/avatar_read.png){width=250}
::: footer ::: ## Neoclassical critique of fiscal policy {.medium} - [Ricardian Equivalence]{.marker-hl}: government spending does not change aggregate demand, as households anticipate that they will pay expenditure as future taxes. - [Crowding out]{.marker-hl}: when governments borrow money, it affects interest rates through the loanable funds market, depressing investment spending and encouraging saving. - [Political pressure]{.marker-hl}: since fiscal policy is done by the government, it needs political support, which may vary from what's actually best for the economy ## Keynesian legitimation for fiscal policy - [Aggregate demand]{.marker-hl} determines economic growth - Lack of aggregate demand and involuntary [unemployment]{.marker-hl} persist - Fiscal policy is essential to reduce economic volatility - Fiscal policy should be [anti-cyclical]{.marker-hl} - [No balanced budget]{.marker-hl} required in the short term - Public investment increases aggregate demand with [multiplier]{.marker-hl} ## The fiscal multiplier {.medium} $$ Y = C(\theta) + I(r) + G + NX $$ . . . $$ C = \alpha_0 + \alpha_1 (1 - \theta) Y $$ . . . $$ Y - \alpha_1(1-\theta)Y = \alpha_0 + I(r) + G + NX $$ . . . $$ \frac{\partial Y}{\partial G} = \frac{1}{(1 - \alpha_1 + \alpha_1 \theta)} $$ . . . $$ \alpha_1 \in (0, 1); \; \theta \in (0, 1); \; \frac{\partial Y}{\partial G} > 1 $$ ## Second-round effects {.medium} $$ \alpha_1 = 0.6; \; \theta = 0.3; $$ Total multiplier: $$ Y^* = 1/(1 - 0.6 + 0.6 \cdot 0.3) \simeq 1.7 $$ First round: $$ \alpha_1 (1-\theta)\Delta Y = 0.6 \cdot (1-0.3) \cdot 1 \simeq 0.4 $$ Second round: $$ 0.6 \cdot (1-0.3) \cdot 0.4 \simeq 0.2 $$ ## Keynes Cross ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576} ::: ## Keynes Cross {visibility="uncounted"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576} ::: ## Keynes Cross {visibility="uncounted"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576} ::: ## Sectoral balances (net lending/net borrowing) {.smaller} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/balances-1.png){width=1152} :::{.aside} Source: Eurostat [tipsnf10] ::: ## Effects of fiscal consolidation on distribution {.smaller} Studies typically find that [inequality increases]{.marker-hl} in periods of fiscal consolidation (with similar data): - @ball:2013: 17 OECD countries from 1978 to 2009 - @agnello:2014: 18 industrialized countries from 1978 to 2009 - @woo:2016: 17 OECD countries from 1980 to 2010 - @heimberger:2020: 17 OECD countries from 1978 to 2013 Data on fiscal consolidation is provided by @devries:2011: "A New Action-based Dataset of Fiscal Consolidation". Narrative approach that focuses on policy actions (tax hikes and/or spending cuts) taken by governments with the intent of reducing the budget deficit. Methodology: Impulse response functions (IRF) from local projections as proposed by @jorda:2005. ## Consolidation episodes {.smaller} ::: {.tbl-classic .tbl-smaller} | Country | Epidodes | Country | Epidodes | |:-------:|:---------|:-------:|:---------| | :australia: | 1985–1988, 1994–1999 | :it: | 1991–1998, 2004–2007, 2010–2013 | | :austria: | 1980–1981, 1984, 1996–1997, 2001–2002, 2011–2013 | :jp: | 1979–1983, 1997–1998, 2003–2007 | | :belgium: | 1982–1985, 1987, 1990, 1992–1994, 1996–1997, 2010–2013 | :netherlands: | 1981–1988, 1991–1993, 2004–2005 | | :canada: | 1984–1997 | :portugal: | 1983, 2000, 2002, 2005–2007, 2010–2013 | | :denmark: | 1983–1986, 1995, 2011–2013 | :es: | 1983–1984, 1989, 1992–1997, 2009–2013 | | :finland: | 1992–1997 | :sweden: | 1984, 1993–1998 | | :fr: | 1979, 1987, 1991, 1995–1997, 2011–2013 | :uk: | 1979–1982, 1994–1999, 2010–2013 | | :de: | 1982–1984, 1991–1995, 1997, 1999–2000, 2003–2004, 2006–2007, 2011–2013 | :us: | 1978, 1980–1981, 1985–1988, 1990–1998, 2011–2013 | | :ireland: | 1982–1988, 2009–2013 | | | : {tbl-colwidths="[10,40,10,40]"} ::: ::: {.aside} Source: @devries:2011 ::: ## Austerity measures have dampened growth in Europe ![](img/austerity.png){fig-align="center" height="500px"} ## Fiscal consolidation increases inequality {.smaller} ![](img/consolidation.png){fig-align="center"} ::: {.aside} Source: @ball:2013 ::: ## Fiscal consolidation: Spending versus taxes {.smaller} ![](img/spending_tax.png){fig-align="center"} ::: {.aside} Source: @ball:2013 ::: ## Larger effect for spending-based consolidation {.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/tax-based.png){fig-align="center"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/spending-based.png){fig-align="center"} ::: :::: ::: {.aside} Source: @woo:2016 ::: ## Fiscal consolidation increases (long-term) unemployment {.smaller} ![](img/unemployment.png){fig-align="center"} ::: {.aside} Source: @ball:2013 ::: # Monetary policy
![](../../data/img/avatar_explain.png){width=250}
::: footer ::: ## Effects of contractionary monetary policy shocks Study by @furceri:2018: - (unanticipated) changes in short-term interest rates for a panel of 32 countries from 1990 to 2013 - contractionary monetary policy shocks increase income inequality, expansionary monetary policy reduces inequality - effect is asymmetric: tightening of monetary policy raises inequality more than easing lowers it ## Effect of monetary policy on output, unemployment and inflation {.smaller} ![](img/monetarypolicy.png){fig-align="center"} ::: {.aside} Source: @furceri:2018 ::: ## Effect of monetary policy shocks on inequality {.smaller} ![](img/monetaryineq.png){fig-align="center" height="500px"} ::: {.aside} Source: @furceri:2018 ::: ## Empirical evidence in single countries is ambiguous {.medium} - @andersen:2023 find for Denmark (1987-2014) that expansionary monetary policy (reduction of rates) leads to more inequality. - @mumtaz:2017 suggest for the United Kingdom (1969-2012) that contractionary monetary policy resulted in increasing income inequality. - @coibion:2017 argue that contractionary monetary policy shocks boosted inequality in the United States since 1980. - @mckay:2023 find that monetary policy has a relatively uniform incidence across households in the United States. # Themes
![](../../data/img/avatar_break.png){width=250}
::: footer ::: ## Themes ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/themes-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960} ::: ## Main theme components {.medium} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data |> ggplot(aes(x = var1, y = var2)) |> geom_line() + theme_minimal() + theme(plot.background = element_rect(fill = "red"), panel.grid.x = element_blank(), axis.line.x = element_line(linewidth = 1.2), legend.text = element_text(size = 7), legend.position = "top") ``` :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
